Idea: Play boozy shuffleboard at this hipster hangout
Description: A worthwhile date in Gowanus used to be practically impossible (a canal full of dead dolphins will do that), but that was before The Royal Palms showed up. Enjoy the cocktails on tap and try your hand at a game and you’ll understand why your Grandma and every hipster in Brooklyn loves it so much.

Idea: Hit up feeding time at the Central Park Zoo
Description: The California sea lions balance balls, catch fish, and interact with their trainers in the cutest ways possible, and their glass-walled enclosure gives visitors a great view of all the action. Go for a walk in the park after, or stick around the zoo and check out the red pandas because, well, they're adorable.

Idea: Play with some cats and sip tea at Meow Parlour
Description: Sipping coffee in a room full of cats is no longer reserved just for the eccentric shut-ins of New York City. The city's first cat cafe features a feline-filled room next to a cafe doling out the same drinks and eats found at their bakeries.

Idea: Scope out the Brooklyn Botanic Garden
Address: 150 Eastern Parkway, 990 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11225
Description: This place may actually be better to visit during the winter than the summer -- especially the hothouses, which are kind of like taking a (sadly overdressed) trip to Costa Rica. Oh, and make sure to tell your date about how the Japanese garden contains a hidden temple dedicated to the wolf spirits.

Idea: Head to Spirited Brooklyn for dessert and booze
Description: Drinks and dessert are always a great first date combo, but booze-filled baked goods at a "dessert speakeasy?" Yeah. Check out the chocolate-whiskey pecan pie -- it tastes exactly as awesome as you’d think.

Idea: Slurp down cheap oysters at a low-key happy hour
Description: Swing by The Saint Austere for dollar oysters any Monday through Saturday from 6-8pm when you can get a mix of East and West Coast specimens. Also, the short-term nature of a happy hour gives either of you an out if a better Tinder match comes up.

Idea: Meet for a DUMBO date at Jane’s Carousel
Address: Jane's Carousel, Brooklyn Bridge Park, Dock St, New York, NY 11201
Description: That refurbished carousel in Brooklyn Bridge Park is kind of endlessly romantic, plus there are a bunch of great dinner options within an easy walking distance: the delicious tequila cocktails at Gran Electrica are just around the corner and don’t require a Grimaldian wait.

Idea: Take in the view at the Met’s Roof Garden Café and Martini Bar
Description: With one of the lushest lawns in the city, the Met’s roof garden is a perfect little oasis in the center of the crowd.

Idea: Sneak into the swimming pool at a hotel
Description: Sneaking into an indoor pool is a great, slightly illicit date for all seasons, and it’s surprising just how many pools you can access in New York. The One UN is a cakewalk: just stroll with purpose to the elevator in the East Tower, go to the 27th floor, and glide into the locker room. Worst case scenario: pretend you’re confused representatives from Estonia. Nobody will be the wiser.

Idea: Sample craft beer on a sailboat
Description: Unlike the first date, you should be reasonably sure you want to spend some time together, so sign up for Manhattan By Sail, which'll include a couple of hours sipping ales, nibbling charcuterie, and taking in the skyline views.

Idea: Explore Brooklyn Flea with a Sofia Mini wine in a can
Address: 176 Lafayette Ave. btw. Clermont + Vanderbilt Ave.
Description: The plan for a perfect lazy Saturday: check out the wares of 100+ vendors while (very discretely) sipping a sparkling wine that comes in a cannister that looks as innocuous as an energy drink -- it's a great way to day drink in style. Oh, and don’t throw out the little straws -- Francis Ford slapped them on when he heard that drinking sparkling wine through a straw makes you get tipsier faster.

Idea: Try your hand at the sketchiest golf in Brooklyn
Description: Hit up the only mini-golf course in town that comes with pickleback shots, and don’t forget to pack your own clubs for this misadventure.

Idea: Grab a handful of quarters and challenge your date to pinball
Address: 402 E 11th St New York, New York
Description: It may look like a skate shop from the outside (and from the inside, mostly because... it’s a skate shop), but Reciprocal on 11th Street is also a pinball arcade.

Idea: Meet for a lunch date by a waterfall
Description: Enjoy the unusual sensation of eating lunch beside a relaxing waterfall in the center of Midtown Manhattan, just one of the many secret spots in the city you can introduce your date to.

Idea: Take in a seriously good jazz show at Shrine
Address: 2271 Adam Clayton Powell Jr Blvd New York,  NY  10030
Description: Head uptown for some of the best jazz in town at a little venue called Shrine. This place (which looks kind of like a bodega on the outside) offers outstanding shows pretty much every night of the week.

Idea: Head uptown for some low-cost deliciousness
Description: Start off at Taco Mix, a standing room-only joint with the best -- and some of the cheapest -- tacos in the entire city (we defy you to spend more than $10 in this place), then mosey over to Amor Cubano for mojitos and desserts.

Idea: Go rock climbing in the middle of the city
Description: Head over to Steep Rock Bouldering to try it out together. They don’t take reservations, but someone is always around to give you a quick tour before setting you loose to figure out how to climb walls. Surprising bonus: they’re open 'til 11pm on weekdays.

Idea: Get your culture going at Moma PS1 Sunday Sessions
Description: On Sundays, the museum offers up a live presentation, which may be anything from dance exhibitions to short films to musical collaborations. These performances are recent works by contemporary artists, dusting some of the must off a typical museum date.

Idea: Ride the Staten Island Ferry
Description: Okay, there may not be a whole lot you want to do once you land in Staten Island (unless you both love pizza), but the boat ride itself -- and view of Lady Liberty -- is well worth the trip.

Idea: Get Balkan at the Bulgarian disco
Address: 113 Ludlow St New York City, New York 10002
Description: Mehanata is some strange magic: this place combines Slavic music, a dance floor, and an ice cage. You and your date can shrug on gigantic overcoats (provided), and enter a freezing room made of ice for two minutes' worth of unlimited shots.

Idea: Dinner and a movie redux
Description: The most classic date of all can be a little too obvious. Mix it up a bit with Nitehawk's Live Sound Cinema, wherein a live band plays against a silent film.

Idea: Stop by UCB’s Asssscat 3000
Description: The 9:30pm Sunday night show is free, but be sure to swing by in advance (around 8:15pm) to snag tickets, as they tend to run out. The performances at this long-form improv show feature some of the funniest people in comedy, frequently including writers from SNL and The Colbert Report.

Idea: Get a picnic packed by Pappardella and enjoy it at The Cloisters
Address: 99 Margaret Corbin Dr; Fort Tryon Park New York,  NY  10033
Description: Surprise your date with your knowledge of the gorgeous views Uptown, and with a well-appointed picnic.

Idea: Go on a tour of Brooklyn Brewery
Description: The brewery offers free, regularly-scheduled tours every Saturday (and they’re only $10 on weekdays). Your opening material is running thin at this point, and this'll fill any silences nicely. So will the beer.

Idea: Take in a Friday night burlesque show
Description: You’ve already been to the dance parties at Hotel Chantelle, but you may not have checked out their awesome ground-floor burlesque show.

Idea: Take a stroll on the High Line
Address: The High Line New York,  NY  10011
Description: Pop in for a drink at Terroir, where you can share your knowledge of how people are often caught having sex in windows of The Standard.

Idea: Head out to Brighton Beach for Russian cuisine
Description: Known as “Little Odessa", Brighton Beach has maybe the best Russian food in the Western hemisphere. Snack on some of the ever-present traditional baked goods (available on basically every street corner), then settle in for a proper meal at Café Restaurant Volna.

Idea: Head to Low Brow Artique for an art opening
Description: Graffiti shop by day, gallery by... well, also day, but also the occasional evening. Come out for an art opening and introduce your date to the awesome street art, PBR, and creative vibe.

Idea: Drink cheap beer and play board games at Boobie Trap
Description: Get competitive over Candyland in this fun, totally lady-friendly (and woman-owned) jugs-themed bar. Everything in the small space is covered in boobs, boobs, and more boobs, but the atmosphere is playful, really! Try coloring in mildly dirty cartoon pictures with crayons while you wait for a plate of their extra-delicious barbecue.

Idea: Take a bartending class at Apotheke
Description: If you’re into learning and drinking (remember college?), then you may want to spend a Saturday making and sipping high-quality drinks from the pros. The courses at Apotheke vary from classic cocktails, to the garden-to-glass variety, to absinthe-bases.

Idea: Pet a penguin at the Long Island Aquarium
Description: Okay, it’s kind of a hike, so you have to be comfortable enough with each other already to train it, but if getting up close and personal with a penguin sounds like your idea of a good time (and your basic humanity should be questioned if it doesn’t), then consider this a good time.

Idea: All-you-can-drink brunch at Amity Hall
Description: This one doubles as a great, immediate follow-up date to a really successful third date. Amity Hall provides one of the best all-you-can-drink brunch deals in the whole city.

Idea: Take the standard dinner date to a new level
Address: 109 Macdougal Street, Suite 2, New York, NY 10012
Description: Miette Culinary Studio offers one-off cooking classes: try out the butchering demo and masterclass, where you learn to prepare things like "a whole grilled grass-fed lamb", or try out one of their delicious -- but less intense -- Italian, Spanish, Indian, or French cooking courses.

Idea: Wake up early to go clubbing
Description: Yeah, you read that right: go on one memorable pre-work date at Daybreaker, the rave that starts at 7am. Throw back some espresso shots and get down on the most unlikely dance floor in the city during the time you’d normally be hitting the gym -- stay tuned for their next party.

Idea: Get some fun sex tips at Babeland brunch
Address: 94 Rivington St, New York, New York 10002
Description: Not for the faint of heart, Babeland offers intriguing ideas (and an array of fun toys) for getting frisky, from oral sex tips to spanking, in a regularly scheduled brunch-time lesson (comes with free muffins!).

Idea: Snack on guinea pigs in Queens
Description: Yeah, yeah, they’re really cute, but they’re also high in protein, low-fat, and totally tasty. Get adventurous and try out this staple of Peruvian cuisine at El Dorado Café.

Idea: Go on the "Satan’s Seat" walking tour
Description: Learn all about the culture in New York during the Roaring Twenties, and stop by some of the country’s most notorious speakeasies. Tours with The Big Onion tend to sell out in advance, so book this one about a week out. Packing a flask, while not encouraged, is simply in keeping with the theme.

Idea: Squeeze a Realdoll at the Museum of Sex
Description: MoSex is often funny, sometimes clinical, always fascinating, and kind of less erotic than you might expect. But it’ll definitely open up more intriguing conversations between you and your date, and after a tour, you can share an aphrodisiac drink and the self-proclaimed best sticky bun in New York in the café.

Idea: Hit up KGB Bar for some beer and poetry
Description: This Village staple offers readings nightly, but the Monday Night Poetry series stands out. The venue has a full bar, so even if you’re not in love with the poet at hand, you can enjoy a good whiskey, then discuss the details with your date after.

Idea: Strap on some masks and take in Sleep No More
Description: Look, if you do Sleep No More together on your fifth date, the immersive strangeness of the experience is going to mean that you’re either dating or you’re about to stop seeing each other. If you’re okay with that gamble, then go forth.

Idea: Angel's Share
Description: Head to Village Yokocho, find a secret door off of the dining room, and head upstairs to the main attraction: one of the best whiskey bars in the city.

Idea: Death & Co
Description: D&C's a high-end, dimly lit sanctuary for both the casual and professional boozist. And while it may be difficult at times to squeeze past the door, when you make it into the dimly lit spot for mixological excellence, you won't even remember that you waited for 45 minutes in the cold.

Idea: PDT
Description: Sure, like Death & Co, this place is one of the most famous bars in the world now. But that doesn't change the fact that it's hidden behind a phone booth in Crif Dogs, which is still totally awesome the first time you do it, and meets the requisite barriers for entry to make this place still somewhat-secret.

Idea: 2nd Floor on Clinton
Description: Located through and above Barramundi, 2nd Floor on Clinton is a small, table service-only reading room adorned with expertly mixed cocktails, like the Between Dogs & Wolves with mezcal, Velvet Falernum, Byrrh Grand Quinquina, grapefruit, lemon, and Bergamot bitters... which sounds exactly like something you'd get at a secret bar.

Idea: Back Room
Description: Located behind a toy store, this '20s-style speakeasy (which claims to be in the same spot as an actual speakeasy from the '20s) serves its booze in teacups. Plus, on Mondays, you can head over for "Speakeasy Dollhouse", an interactive & immersive theater performance that promises "revolving bookshelves, mystery, and intrigue".
